This is *not* about what people *think* his sentence should be.

text:
None of which is to suggest Barr isn’t up to the job. He’s a widely respected attorney (as we’ve noted on air). 

But these are self-contradictory claims, with a factual error, about a *core act under investigation in the Mueller probe* — the firing of FBI Director Comey.
author: AriMelber

text:
So Barr’s reversal — saying ‘Comey was right’ until it became Trump’s (initial) excuse for firing Comey, then saying ‘Comey was wrong’ — relies on something that was not true. 

Questioning why Barr claimed otherwise, and his motivations, could be a fruitful avenue under oath.
author: AriMelber

text:
Barr defends his reversal by claiming he thought DOJ authorized Comey’s July statement on Clinton — but Comey said the *opposite* at the top of that address:

“I have not coordinated or reviewed this statement in any way with the DOJ.. They do not know what I am about to say.”
author: AriMelber

text:
Both assertions came in WashPo op-eds he wrote defending Republicans at key inflection points, the final week of the 2016 campaign an days after the Comey firing. Headlines:

“COMEY DID THE RIGHT THING” (10/16)

“TRUMP MADE RIGHT CALL ON [FIRING] COMEY” (5/17)
author: AriMelber

text:
Senators may also question why...

Barr went from praising Comey in Oct. 2016, saying his announcing no charges against Clinton did not appear to usurp power — to  citing that same action as “crossing a line” that justified Trump firing him.
author: AriMelber

text:
In Bill Barr’s hearing, watch for questions about not only respecting Mueller’s independence — but the independence of prosecutors investigating Trump issues in the Southern District of NY.

(As discussed with @neal_katyal ; cc former SDNY US Attorneys @PreetBharara @Comey )

text: And note that example combines these *two areas of accountability* — lies impacting people’s money and lies getting busted in court — to force a man who lied about “never settling cases” to settle, and give the customers he’d conned their money back.
author: AriMelber

text:
The big Q is whether enough bubbles pop to inoculate people against Trump’s lies *going forward*

Trump U. is the classic example. It not only failed, but left some of Trump’s biggest fans — paying Trump U. customers — angrily demanding their money back from him

And they got it.
author: AriMelber

text: And as President, Trump has proven to be both canny and impulsive — it’s obviously against his political self-interest to be forcing a made-up shutdown during this market drop, apparently from impulse; while he continues to try to beat back legal accountability with his AG picks.
author: AriMelber

text: It’s not exactly a ‘good thing’ that courts and markets provide faster backlash than other parts of our democratic system — any con man can see the other areas where lies work with more impunity and focus on exploiting those — but it’s telling that Trump is hurting in these areas
author: AriMelber

text: Thread for today’s market slide and Trump vs facts:
author: AriMelber

text:
In court — where *lying is a crime* — Trump has already had more former aides indicted and convicted than any other first term president in history.

And in the markets, where being wrong is *expensive,* there’s a swift backlash to his shutdown and economic policies:
author: AriMelber

text: So even one argues Trump has “gotten away” with more lies than a typical POTUS — sanctioned less by the political system, paying less of a price with his base (while Bush was pummeled for 1 lie about new taxes) — consider the two areas where Trump is facing swift backlash...
author: AriMelber

text: This approach can shape public opinion in the short run, but that “propaganda effect” feeds bubbles which can eventually pop. Some things are easier to lie about than others...

author: AriMelber

text: Thank you — there’s a temptation for the press to cover this as “another step in a cycle of partisanship by both sides” when it’s more like the opposite — a one-sided attack on democracy’s transfer of power itself.
author: AriMelber

text: To protect democracy, these anti-democratic schemes must not only lose in the courts and in public opinion. They must be punished so aggressively,  by judges and voters, that this is no longer considered any kind of legitimate option in the first place.
author: AriMelber

text: Put ethics to the side, and perhaps it's not surprising that a party struggling to achieve national electoral majorities — Republicans won *fewer* votes than Democrats in *6 of the past 7* presidential races — is using tricks to cement power that cannot be won at the ballot box.
author: AriMelber

text:
Republicans in WI also deploy gerrymandering to rig the outcomes of their elections.

More WI voters backed Democrats in their state assembly races last month -- but the GOP was still able to “win” control of 64% of the district seats.
author: AriMelber

text:
Some argue the WI legislature has the power to reform these offices. That may be technically accurate, but misses the point. The legislature has powers to organize the gov. 

The issue is whether explicitly legislating to undermine election results is an *abuse* of those powers.
author: AriMelber

text:
The GOP ploy in Wisconsin, echoing Republicans in N. Carolina, is *not* part of a “cycle of partisan warfare.” It is not “another round” of political payback that pundits can debate through the narrow lens of clever strategy. 

It is antithetical to democracy.
author: AriMelber

text:
Wisconsin Republicans are undercutting a core premise of our democracy — that the people leaving office have an obligation to transfer their powers peacefully and professionally. This is not normal.

My new @washingtonpost piece:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2018/12/06/what-it-means-democracy-if-losers-elections-dont-relinquish-power/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.b304bf701839 …

text: There are also contrasts to @THEREALSWIZZZ situation — he paid the IRS what he owed, he didn’t commit election crimes, or lie to a bank or Congress, or pursue business with a sanctioned Kremlin bank for a politician trying to nix those sanctions possibly  for personal profit.

text:
Cohen’s lawyer also argues @THEREALSWIZZZ paid over half a million in back taxes and did no time.

This raises the question, does Cohen’s lawyer know *Swizz produced DMX’s Ruff Ryders Anthem,* gesturing towards a blending of both musical style and tax evasion style?
author: AriMelber

text: They cite DMX because his *advisory* sentencing range was about 5 years and he only got 1 — so it’s a precedent for how some convicts get far less than the advisory length, based on other factors.
author: AriMelber

text:
In other words, “The lawyers / the part / they are / of the puzzle / 
The release / the warning, "Try not to get in trouble!” / The snitches / the odds / probation / parole / The new charge / the bail / the warrant / the hole!”
author: AriMelber

text: They cite the case depicting DMX concealing millions to avoid paying taxes, routing payments to his managers so money could be “distributed to himself in cash.”
author: AriMelber

text:
In the sentencing memo, Michael Cohen’s lawyer argues Cohen’s tax evasion was not as bad as DMX, who served a year in jail (U.S. v. Earl Simmons).

The problem with this argument is that a lot of things aren’t as bad as DMX.
author: AriMelber

text: Right tariff wars are literally recent and ancient history, as a policy matter. As a journalistic story, the book would be about half as long without sources close to Gary Cohn and sources familiar with Gary Cohn’s thinking.
author: AriMelber

text: And the depiction of the trade debate is odd — presents Trump’s approach as unique and dangerous, but even if his trade policies fail, they fit into a long history of trade controversies that run the ideological gambit (Perot, Sanders, etc)
author: AriMelber

text: There’s no wider analysis — which may be Woodward’s version of “Just the facts/quotes” — so it’s not a big take or history of the start of this presidency.
author: AriMelber

text: Overall, this isn’t a broad book about the Trump presidency. It’s about internal strife about 3 main issues - trade, foreign policy and the Mueller probe - with a heavy dose of the perspective from critics in those areas (especially Cohn).
author: AriMelber

text: There’s also an interesting defense of the Dowd-Cobb cooperation strategy, which is now one of the most controversial moves among Trump’s remaining legal advisors.
author: AriMelber

text: Woodward also reports Trump didn’t understand he did NOT have attorney client privilege with Cobb, as a WH lawyer. And Trump later bemoaned how much he told him. Yikes.
author: AriMelber

text:
Obviously it serves the President poorly to have attorney client counsel leak in a criminal probe. 

Several parts of the book are heavy with things Dowd saw or thought.
author: AriMelber

text: Dowd calls Trump on AF1 - who is leaking this privileged call? It would seem to be a call between client, lawyer and *maybe* a trusted Trump confidante on AF1.
author: AriMelber

text: Some of the most remarkable leaks are the ones breaking attorney-client privilege between Dowd and POTUS.
author: AriMelber

text:
“Precedent on precedent” - Kavanaugh arguing Roe is like a super-precedent because SCOTUS reaffirmed the core right to abortion in Roe *and* Casey. 

“Precedent on precedent” is a jurisprudential version of “Racks on racks on racks,” or even “Maybachs on bachs on bachs.”
author: AriMelber

It can be hard to follow agency law debates in the abstract. 

In concrete terms, Kavanaugh’s concern about the power of federal agencies has meant skepticism towards federal efforts to regulate Wall St after the financial crisis and efforts to protect the environment.

text:
And today, people are more concerned about someone rifling through their *phone* than going through their bedroom drawers. So what does the Bill of Rights mean online?

We need this debate - with accountability, with CEOs under oath in Congress - and a bit less techsplaining.
author: AriMelber

text:
But when these companies fight any and all regulation so much, that they suppress any public-private partnership to address these problems, the backlash you earn can be so great that you actually become a handmaiden to your own "over-regulation."
FB might be headed for that.
author: AriMelber

text: Tech companies have a point saying that a rush to enact  broad regulation, in response to a particular problem of the moment, can cause more problems than it solves.
author: AriMelber

text: Now, the drawback to regulation is potential interference with vital innovation. In history, many smart people in Congress (or agencies) were unable to foresee what might be valuable to society, and who made poor regulatory decisions as a result.
author: AriMelber

text: And FB touts their technical acumen for every possible part of the site, except when it comes to resolving problems like these. When they want to fix something, they're pretty good at  doing so. When they don’t, the lectures come about how impossible it is to do things.
author: AriMelber

text: ..and of how long it takes Congress to study issues, create agencies, and write laws. Right now, it’s just a patchwork of some media regulation, some Federal Trade  Commission regulation, and whatever Congress does or doesn’t do to  update existing election laws.
author: AriMelber

text: Tech companies are so new that— by virtue of their  youth—they have never been regulated like older industries. That isn't the product of any considered  judgment that they don't merit regulation. It's an accidental result of how new they are..
author: AriMelber

text: Then there is #Regulation - Zuckerberg now claims he's open to it maybe; but his company paid lobbyists to oppose proposed election disclosure rules for Facebook. The new talk isn't "just talk" - it's misleading based on FB's actual lobbying record.
author: AriMelber

text: And thanks to a whistleblower, we are learning Cambridge touted its web manipulation, “information dominance,” and alternative facts—which overlaps with a key tenet of the Trump campaign.
author: AriMelber

text: This is the digital firm Trump chose, run by Bannon and the Mercers, who specifically asked if Cambridge could help boost the impact of stolen material released by Wikileaks... that is a *window* into a mindset, even if no technical law was broken.
author: AriMelber

text:
Now @jaywillis asks, Did Cambridge break the law?.. and we don't know. 

They caught a search warrant in London today, and Mueller is interested, but the answer could def ultimately be no.

But we do know...
author: AriMelber

text:
Any company will pursue profits. But FB has an inherent conflict: They claim to  treat users as customers, or "community," but as many tech experts have shown, the customers are *actually the product.*

Users come not second for  Facebook, but something like fourth or fifth.
author: AriMelber

text:
..Focusing on the minutiae of rules can come at the expense of looking at the moral and societal questions. 

Facebook lost $50B because people are learning about this company's core conflict between its business model and the personal rights of its user base.
author: AriMelber

text: With stories like this, people tend to first look at what *rules* have been broken... like FB's app rules that developers agree to, or other laws and regulations that are implicated. BUT...
author: AriMelber

text: The Cambridge-Facebook story is important .. not just because of Russia or Trump or Zuckerberg or John Bolton (who used Cambridge) or Bannon or Peter Thiel or the tremendous number of intersections of important people in this story.
author: AriMelber

... about Facebook

text:
Does Trump have the legal authority to personally fire Mueller?

No.

Mueller can be removed "#only by the personal action of the Attorney General." 

28 CFR 600.7:

Trump admits he fired FBI Director over Russia

Trump reportedly ordered firing of Special Counsel Mueller, backing off to avoid a Sat Night Massacre 

Trump reportedly ordered firing of Deputy FBI Director, backing off to avoid a Sat Night Massacre
author: AriMelber

text:
Under DOJ rules, the special counsel can *only* be removed for cause, defined in writing by supervising prosecutor (Rosenstein).

A presidential attempt to fire him without cause could be found unlawful - indeed a court might ultimately overrule it.
author: AriMelber

text:
WH lawyer is NOT currently denying this NYT report. He declines to comment. 

There is no apparent legal reason a WH would need to refrain from denying an attempt to (perhaps unlawfully) have a special counsel fired. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/25/us/politics/trump-mueller-special-counsel-russia.html …
author: AriMelber

text: Note one key reason a government lawyer may legitimately resist a presidential order — if carrying it out itself could be a *crime,* like obstructing an investigation.

Default to a simpler narrative is very human... was just reading Oliver Sacks, who says the brain doesn't recall objective truth very well, so "our only truth is narrative truth, the stories we tell each other and ourselves."

( https://www.amazon.com/River-Consciousness-Oliver-Sacks/dp/0385352565 … )
author: AriMelber

text:
And when the Electoral College keeps putting the national runner-up in the White House - it's happened FIVE times now in US history - a democracy might reckon with how democratic that really is, *regardless* of partisan implications. 

(And reckon with it lawfully, as always.)
author: AriMelber

text: Trump's narrow 2nd place *victory* did not define 'who we are' any more than Roy Moore's narrow second place *loss* defines the true Alabama. (Similar results, different election outcomes.) When just under half an electorate backs those candidates, society has to reckon with why.
author: AriMelber

text: The larger point is not blue or red, and it's pretty simple, of course, not everything fits into one narrative.
author: AriMelber

text: Reporting those facts is not any insult to Doug Jones or gift to Hillary Clinton.  They are just facts.
author: AriMelber

text:
People say Tuesday's result shows a rejection of Moore/Trump.  By that logic, note that voters rejected Trump in 2016 by an even wider margin.

Jones won by about 1.5% - Clinton won about 2.1% more votes.

(Electoral college is law, but ≠ mandate)
author: AriMelber

text:
And Tuesday showed Trump falling among the most important people in politics for the next year - people who VOTE in off-year elections.

Trump Alabama vote share in 2016: 62%
Trump Alabama approval Tue: 48%

text:
DOJ rules for a special counsel require:

(1) A criminal probe is warranted
(2) The DOJ prosecutor who would lead it has conflict or extraordinary circumstance
(3) Public interest warrants a special counsel 

(1) is the first big hurdle - evidence warranting a criminal probe
author: AriMelber

text: Just spoke to Jay Sekulow who says, “This is about an alleged conflict regarding Fusion GPS and Bruce Orr, and it has nothing to do with Bob Mueller or Mueller’s team.” He stresses that was and remains his original point.

4) A crime occurred, part of a broader conspiracy, with smoking gun evidence that goes to the top of the gov & to POTUS.

Example: Watergate
author: AriMelber

text:
3) A crime occurred, part of a broader conspiracy, and charges go to the very top of the organization.

Example: Enron
author: AriMelber

text:
2) A crime occurred, appears to be part of broader conspiracy, but no charges for the top of the organization.

Example: Iran-Contra
author: AriMelber

text: Example of 1: Russian spy indicted last year in the US, by Preet Bharara; case included contact with Carter Page but he was *not* charged.
author: AriMelber

text:
1) A crime occurred, but doesn't involve the Americans under investigation.

They were unwitting attendees, witnesses or even victims.

text: THIS MAY BE THE FIRST 'THREAD' ABOUT THE 2016 ELECTION
author: AriMelber

text: So, some his & lows from What Happened. I'd actually rec reading Remnick's article on it over the actual book, unless you have lots of time.
author: AriMelber

text: That's our Constitution and it ain't changing soon. We can accept it as the rule of law without pretending it's majority rule. It's not.
author: AriMelber

text: The raw truth is our political system may put the runner-up in the White House, and ask the winner to "take responsibility" for losing.
author: AriMelber

text: That's no comfort for [Dems or gun control advocates], but it's bizarre to then pretend the winner "won" by being more popular.
author: AriMelber

text: The factual reality is the more popular thing can lose in an non-pure-democratic system, like the Senate or Electoral College.
author: AriMelber

text: So HRC 2016 is a bit like a gun background check vote in the Senate - the policy can be nationally popular AND lose the Senate vote.
author: AriMelber

text: while I happen to think HRC campaign was run in a mediocre way, if 40k voters swung in a few states there'd be no essays on "why she lost"
author: AriMelber

text: Instead she often joins the narrative of "why Clinton lost," as if more voters chose Trump...
author: AriMelber

text: So if anyone would hammer that, you'd think it would be her, in her campaign book.
author: AriMelber

text: All said and done, and more voters chose her. She was more popular. And she was the first woman nominee to boot.
author: AriMelber

text: Weirdly for a politician, tho, Clinton doesn't hammer her popular victory that much. She won a lot more votes...
author: AriMelber

text: Trump "drove" policy message by acting out, and voters heard more about wall, jobs and swamp in addition to his antics
author: AriMelber

text: Her argument on jobs and media ignoring virtually any message she offered, while slamming her lack of message, should be taught in J school
author: AriMelber

text: Some of it reads as narrow and self-pitting; people are allowed to feel and express that after loss. (Esp if they're told to "be authentic")
author: AriMelber

text: It also shows Clinton at her empirical core - the numbers, the data, the evidence. That's useful (even if it's not headline grabbing)
author: AriMelber

text: And this is a useful book for an accounting of Russia and 2016 - one historians will probably rely on more than many HRC interviews
author: AriMelber

text: Clinton is most revealing on the campaign strategy - frustrations running against a candidate like Trump; inside view of decisions, media
author: AriMelber
